_exec_summary.SummaryText:
THE CITY OF SALISBURY WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 
12-9-04

1.	The City of Salisbury Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) has developed an Emergency Response Plan which complies with OSHA's 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management standard and the US EPA's Emergency Response Plan.  The plan provides employees guidance on what to do in case of a chemical discharge emergency.  

	WWTP Leadership plans to fully update and implement all portions of the 	Plan as soon as possible.  Our near term goals include:
	Continue training our personnel for a chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide leak/chemical emergency
	Continue Plan coordination efforts with the Wicomico County Emergency Services (LEPC).  A table top Haz-Mat Team drill is projected for April 2005.  A field Haz-Mat Team drill is projected for May 2005.  Representatives of the LEPC, City Fire Department, and City Water Division leadership met, with the above dates for drills being projected.  

The original in - house Haz - Mat Team proved to be impractical, due to 	the followed issues:  

	Haz - Mat Team staffing requirements exceeded available WWTP personnel.  
	Guaranteed Workmen's Compensation injury coverage, through the Heart and Lung Law was not available for our personnel. 

	Now that the City Fire Department (FD) has formed a Haz - Mat Team, we 	are revising the Plan to incorporate their assistance:

	In the event of a leak, the FD will be contacted to provide Haz - Mat Team response.  The LEPC will be contacted as well. 
	WWTP Leadership/personnel will act as liaison to the FD Command and Control.  
	All other WWTP personnel will be evacuated.   

2.	The City of Salisbury WWTP now treats approximately 5.5 million gallons per day of wastewater.

4.	The leak detectors are still fully functional, giving audible and light alarms.  

5.	The status of the various components of the Plant general accidental release prevention program is as follows:
	The preventive maintenance program documentation continues to be improved.	
	The leak detectors within the Chlorination/Dechlorination building are calibrated by a qualified service company. 
	The WWTP staff continues to be skilled, working with new personnel in a team approach.  As stated previously, training will be brought to up to a proper level, with associated documentation. 
	Standard Operating Guidelines, including transferring and changing cylinders will be formulated and instituted.  
	A process safety management and risk management audit was performed by an EPA representative on 12-1-04.

6.	There

have been no reportable accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide, at the WWTP, since the initial RMP/PSM Plan submittal (> 5 years).  

7.  The following changes to improve safety for ourselves and the community have been accomplished:
	A documentation form for cylinder hoist inspection has been  	instituted.
	Replacement of the tank flexible feed lines once per year.  
	A permanent water feed line was installed, serving the Chlorination/Dechlorination Building.
	Use of an automatic valve closing system was researched, and determined to be undesirable.   A previous user recommended against installing the system. They experienced excessive pressure being placed on the tank valves, when closing occurred.  They ultimately removed the system from use. 

8.	The Chlorination/Dechlorination system will be removed from service within the next three years.  It is being replaced by an Ultra Violet disinfection system, as part of a Plant upgrade.
